title.narrative: Building Community Capacity for Dispute Resolution and Reconciliation in Lebanon

description.narrative:
The project aims to improve the capacity of community to identify and respond to sectarian and other tensions in the northern city of Tripoli. Target areas include six neighborhoods in Tripoli: Bab al-Tabbaneh, Qobeh, Aswak, Zahiryeh, Mina and Beddawi. The project will directly address the volatile environment in Tripoli by focusing on mitigating the existing sources of instability that drive young people to engage in high-risk behavior. It will create a network of on-the-ground peace mediators equipped with the tools to identify and manage conflicts between contentious groups before they spiral into aggressive confrontation. It will work directly with these groups to devise cooperative mechanisms to problem solve the root causes of these tensions and take joint action to achieve tangible results. It will help community members link their local efforts to a wider strategy for national change, so that their work is supported by an enabling environment and responsive government.
Conflict is multi-dimensional. It does not happen only because communication has broken down or relationships are injured. It does not happen only when people are poor, or living in areas where natural resources are under strain. It happens when all of these factors come together and reinforce each other. The project is geared to this complexity and is designed to use dialogue and development to bridge divides, bring people together and begin the process of reconciliation. Mercy Corps has used this approach in some of the world’s toughest places, including Iraq, Somalia, Pakistan and Yemen, and has produced tangible results. Three core components comprise the basis of the project:
1. Promoting Dialogue and Rebuilding Relationships 2. Addressing the Causes of Conflict 3. Impact and Advocacy

sector.narrative: Conflict Prevention and Resolution/Peace and Security
